DOC.HEAD: Shoemaker Says It Needs Time to Consider $900 Million Takeover Offer
DOC.TEXT: Sride Rite Corp., the leading U.S. maker and retailer of children's footwear, said Thursday it will ignore a Dec. 28 deadline for a response to an investment company's $900 million takeover offer. John J. Phelan, treasurer and executive vice president of Stride Rite, released a letter saying his company would not make an immediate decision on the $32 per-share offer from a group led by Walsh, Greenwood & Co. of Greenwich, Conn. Walsh, Greenwood had requested that Stride Rite come to a conclusion on the matter by Dec. 28. ``That request is quite unreasonable as it would provide us with only four business days to consider the matter,'' Phelan wrote in the letter addressed to Walsh, Greenwood Managing General Partner Stephen Walsh. Phelan wrote that the Stride Rite board would discuss the matter in early January and would respond to Walsh, Greenwood at that time. Walsh, Greenwood and FS Champ Associates, representing the Minda Bronfman de Gunzburg family trusts as a limited partner, made the offer Wednesday. Walsh, Greenwood, which has owned 4.9 percent of Stride Rite since last February, announced Wednesday it would consider other options after the Dec. 28 deadline and might go directly to stockholders with an offer. As the offer was made some analysts lowered their estimates of Stride Rite earnings, partly because of the volume of shoes the company sells to financially troubled Campeau Corp., which owns department store chains that may seek Chapter 11 federal bankruptcy protection because of heavy debts. On the New York Stock Exchange Thursday morning, Stride Rite stock was up 3], to 26~. The Walsh, Greenwood offer was announced just before the market closed Wednesday. Stride Rite reported earnings of $34.7 million, or $1.27 a share, for the fiscal year ended Nov. 30, 1988. Phelan predicted the company's earnings for the 1989 fiscal year will be at the lower end of estimates, from $1.70 to $1.80 per share, and for the 1990 fiscal year from $2 to $2.20 per share, which is lower than Wall Street estimates. In its purchase offer, Walsh, Greenwood said, ``We have no plans to change the manner of the company's operation or the location of its headquarters and principal facilities.'' Stride Rite, based in Cambridge, Mass., is the leading children's shoemaker and retailer in the country, with more than 180 stores and more than 60 sections in department stores. It also manufactures boating and outdoor recreational shoes and adult workboots, and imports athletic and casual wear.
